entry.title: Combined summary - P2QRH / BIP-360 Update
entry.summary:
The ongoing discussions within the Bitcoin Development Community have centered around the integration of post-quantum cryptographic schemes into the Bitcoin protocol, with a particular emphasis on how these changes affect hierarchical deterministic wallets, multisignature setups, and overall blockchain security. The discourse has highlighted the challenges and considerations that arise when attempting to reconcile the cutting-edge demands of quantum-resistant algorithms with the established practices and standards of the cryptocurrency world.
One concern raised involves the potential impact of post-quantum schemes, like FALCON, on the management and backup processes for private keys. The question is whether adopting such schemes would necessitate generating a new wallet backup with every new public key creation, presenting a significant shift in user experience and security protocol. The conversation also revisits the adequacy of current security measures, suggesting that matching the security levels provided by the well-vetted ECDSA could be sufficient for future-proofing against quantum threats. This stance advocates for a balance between advancing cryptographic security and maintaining practicality and usability in user interactions with cryptocurrency systems.
Significant updates to BIP-360, accessible through a detailed [draft](https://github.com/cryptoquick/bips/blob/p2qrh/bip-0360.mediawiki), reflect a strategic pivot in algorithm selection away from SQIsign due to its impractical verification times which could expose the network to DDoS risks. The focus has shifted towards algorithms like FALCON, known for efficient signature aggregation, alongside SPHINCS+ and CRYSTALS-Dilithium as auxiliary options. However, the transition faces technical obstacles such as compatibility issues with BIP-32 and the intricacies of implementing multisig configurations under the new cryptographic paradigm. Proposed solutions include a merkle tree-based approach for multisig outputs and potential modifications to OP_CHECKMULTISIG, though these ideas require further exploration and consensus within the community.
Additionally, the discussion touches on the necessity of conforming to NIST-approved algorithms for FIPS compliance, highlighting the readiness of certain hardware security modules (HSMs) to support these advanced cryptographic functions. This compatibility is crucial for securing federated L2 treasuries using state-of-the-art cryptography.
An interim solution named P2TRH has been proposed to specifically address quantum security concerns associated with Taproot keypath spends. This approach involves hashing public keys rather than exposing them directly, offering benefits for various applications at the cost of some overhead and reduced utility in specific use cases. The community has been urged to provide feedback on this and other proposals through review and commentary on an active [pull request](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1670).
The push towards finalizing post-quantum cryptographic (PQC) selections underscores the importance of community involvement and feedback in shaping the quantum-resistant evolution of Bitcoin. The effort to refine BIP-360 and related proposals will continue to be a focal point at upcoming conferences and events, emphasizing the collaborative nature of securing Bitcoinâ€™s future against emerging quantum threats.
